questions.statement: The SI unit of electric current is the ampere.
questions.explanation: The SI Unit of electric current is the ampere.
questions.source_section: Electric Current as a Flow of Charges

questions.statement: The SI unit of charge is Volt.
questions.explanation: The SI unit of charge (Q) is Coulomb (C).' Volt is the unit of potential difference.
questions.source_section: Electric Current as a Flow of Charges

questions.statement: Protons are negatively charged.
questions.explanation: Protons are positively charged'. Electrons are negatively charged.
questions.source_section: Electric Current as a Flow of Charges

questions.statement: Electrons are negatively charged.
questions.explanation: Electrons are negatively charged
questions.source_section: Electric Current as a Flow of Charges

questions.statement: Neutrons are neutral and have no charge.
questions.explanation: Neutrons do not have any charge, that is, they are neutral.
questions.source_section: Electric Current as a Flow of Charges

questions.statement: The nucleus of an atom consists of electrons and neutrons.
questions.explanation: It consists of protons and neutrons.' Electrons revolve around the nucleus.
questions.source_section: Electric Current as a Flow of Charges

questions.statement: Electrons revolve around the nucleus in paths called orbits.
questions.explanation: Electrons revolve around the nucleus in paths called orbits.
questions.source_section: Electric Current as a Flow of Charges

questions.statement: The direction of conventional current is from negative to positive terminal.
questions.explanation: The direction of flow of electric current is taken to be from the positive terminal of the battery... to the negative terminal.

questions.statement: The direction of conventional current is opposite to the direction of flow of electrons.
questions.explanation: The direction of the conventional current is taken to be opposite to the direction of flow of electrons.

questions.statement: A dry cell can be recharged after use.
questions.explanation: The dry cell commonly used in torches is an example of a primary cell. It cannot be recharged after use.

questions.statement: Secondary cells can be recharged.
questions.explanation: Secondary cells are used in automobiles and generators. The chemical reaction on them can be reversed, hence they can be recharged.

questions.statement: The dry cell was developed in 1887 by Yai Sakizo of Japan.
questions.explanation: It was developed in 1887 by Yai Sakizo of Japan.

questions.statement: In a dry cell, the zinc container acts as the positive electrode.
questions.explanation: A dry cell essentially consists of a zinc container, acting as the negative electrode.

questions.statement: In a dry cell, the carbon rod acts as the positive electrode.
questions.explanation: A carbon rod with a brass cap is placed at the centre. This acts as a positive electrode

questions.statement: The positive electrode is called the cathode.
questions.explanation: The positive electrode is called the anode, while the negative electrode is called the cathode.

questions.statement: Secondary cells are also called storage cells or accumulators.
questions.explanation: Secondary cells are also called storage cells or accumulators.

questions.statement: A battery is formed by connecting cells in parallel.
questions.explanation: A number of primary cells connected in series forms a battery.

questions.statement: An electric generator converts mechanical energy into electrical energy.
questions.explanation: An electric generator or dynamo is a device that converts mechanical energy into electrical energy.

questions.statement: In hydroelectric power stations, turbines are rotated by wind.
questions.explanation: In hydroelectric power stations, turbines are rotated by flowing water.

questions.statement: A thermal power plant uses fossil fuels to produce electricity.
questions.explanation: A thermal power plant uses energy produced from fossil fuels such as coal, diesel or natural gas

questions.statement: Solar cells convert electrical energy into solar energy.
questions.explanation: The device used to convert solar energy into electrical energy is called the solar cell.' It's the opposite.

questions.statement: Solar panels are used in artificial satellites and space stations.
questions.explanation: Solar panels are used in artificial satellites and space stations.

questions.statement: The more the speed of wind, the less electricity is generated.
questions.explanation: The more the speed of the wind, the more will be its energy and thus more electricity is generated.

questions.statement: An electric circuit is a closed path in which electric current flows.
questions.explanation: An electric circuit is defined as a closed path in which electric current flows.

questions.statement: A circuit is said to be open when electric current flows through it.
questions.explanation: A circuit is said to be open when no electric current flows through it.

questions.statement: When a circuit is connected in series, if one appliance stops working, other appliances connected in the series also stop working.
questions.explanation: If any appliance gets damaged, the remaining appliances also stop working because the circuit gets broken due to the damaged appliance.

questions.statement: In a parallel circuit, all appliances depend upon each other to complete the circuit.
questions.explanation: In case of parallel connection, the electrical appliances are not dependent upon each other to complete the circuit.

questions.statement: In household wiring systems, all appliances are connected in series.
questions.explanation: In household wiring system, all the appliances are connected in parallel with separate switches.

questions.statement: In a series circuit, each appliance gets the original voltage.
questions.explanation: The text states: In series circuit 'There is a sharing of voltage (potential difference).' In parallel circuit 'Each appliance gets the original voltage.

questions.statement: A resistor opposes the flow of current in a circuit.
questions.explanation: A resistor which opposes the flow of current in the circuit.

questions.statement: Copper is an insulator.
questions.explanation: All metals such as copper, silver, nickel, aluminium, iron and steel are conductors.

questions.statement: Plastic is a good conductor of electricity.
questions.explanation: Cotton, rubber, paper, glass, ceramics, plastic, wood and pure water are insulators.

questions.statement: Pure water is an insulator.
questions.explanation: Pure water are insulators.

questions.statement: Impure water is a conductor of electricity.
questions.explanation: Impure water is also a conductor.

questions.statement: Air is a conductor of electricity.
questions.explanation: Air is an insulator.

questions.statement: A switch can be touched with wet hands safely.
questions.explanation: Do not touch electrical appliances and switches with wet hands

questions.statement: Cotton is a good conductor of electricity.
questions.explanation: Cotton, rubber, paper, glass, ceramics, plastic, wood and pure water are insulators.

questions.statement: All power lines are well insulated.
questions.explanation: The text (Myth vs Fact) states: 'In fact, 90% of outside power lines are bare wires and uninsulated.

questions.statement: The human body can conduct electricity.
questions.explanation: The human body also allows current to pass through it

questions.statement: An electrochemical cell converts electrical energy into chemical energy.
questions.explanation: It converts chemical energy into electrical energy.' It's the opposite.

questions.statement: The centre of an atom is called the nucleus.
questions.explanation: The centre of the atom is called the nucleus.
questions.source_section: Electric Current as a Flow of Charges

questions.statement: 1 Volt = 1 Joule / 1 Coulomb.
questions.explanation: 1 Volt = 1 Joule/ 1 Coulomb.

questions.statement: The unit Volt is named after American scientist Benjamin Franklin.
questions.explanation: It is named after the Italian Physicist Alessandro Volta.

questions.statement: Electric current flows only when there is a potential difference.
questions.explanation: Thus, an electric current flows only when there is a potential difference.

questions.statement: The carbon rod in a dry cell has a copper cap on top.
questions.explanation: A carbon rod with a brass cap is placed at the centre.

questions.statement: The electrolyte in a dry cell is a moist paste of ammonium chloride and plaster of Paris.
questions.explanation: The electrolyte is a moist paste of ammonium chloride (NH4Cl) and plaster of Paris.

questions.statement: A dry cell is completely dry inside with no moisture.
questions.explanation: The dry cell is not really dry in nature but the quantity of water in it is very less, as the electrolyte is in the form of a paste.

questions.statement: It is safe to open a dry cell to see inside.
questions.explanation: Never try to open a dry cell. The chemicals inside are harmful.

questions.statement: Lead accumulator is an example of a primary cell.
questions.explanation: Examples of secondary cells are lead accumulator, Edison accumulator and nickel-iron accumulator.

questions.statement: Voltaic cell is an example of a primary cell.
questions.explanation: Examples of primary cells are simple voltaic cell, Daniel cell, Leclanche cell and dry cell.

questions.statement: Electricity for domestic purposes is generated at electric power stations.
questions.explanation: Electricity for domestic and industrial purposes is generated at electric power stations.

questions.statement: In a generator, an electric conductor is kept stationary to produce current.
questions.explanation: In a generator, an electric conductor such as copper wire is rotated in a magnetic field to produce an electric current.

questions.statement: A nuclear power plant uses nuclear energy to generate electric current.
questions.explanation: An atomic or nuclear power plant uses nuclear energy to generate electric current.

questions.statement: Solar cells can power electronic calculators and watches.
questions.explanation: Solar cells are used to power electronic calculators, watches, streetlights and lighthouses.

questions.statement: A solar panel is formed by a single large solar cell.
questions.explanation: A solar panel is formed by a large number of solar cells connected together.

questions.statement: Windmills generate electricity by using the energy of flowing water.
questions.explanation: The energy of the wind is used to rotate the blades of a windmill, which in turn, generates electricity.

questions.statement: A switch helps in making and breaking of the circuit.
questions.explanation: An electric switch to turn on or off the electric device' and 'Helps in making and breaking of the circuit'.
questions.source_section: Components of an Electric Circuit and Their Functions

questions.statement: A plug key helps in keeping a circuit open or closed for longer duration.
questions.explanation: A plug key which helps in keeping a circuit open or closed for longer duration.
questions.source_section: Components of an Electric Circuit and Their Functions

questions.statement: A circuit is said to be closed when the switch is off.
questions.explanation: A circuit is said to be closed or complete when electric current flows through it. This condition is obtained when the switch is on.

questions.statement: Electric current flows only in a closed circuit.
questions.explanation: The text (Activity conclusion) states: 'Electric current flows only in a closed circuit.

questions.statement: A circuit diagram shows the path of electric current using conventional symbols.
questions.explanation: A circuit diagram is a convenient way to show the path of electric current on paper by using conventional symbols.

questions.statement: In a series circuit, all appliances work simultaneously.
questions.explanation: Series circuit: All appliances work simultaneously.

questions.statement: In a parallel circuit, all appliances work independently.
questions.explanation: Parallel circuit: All appliances work independently.

questions.statement: In a parallel circuit, if any appliance gets damaged, all remaining appliances stop working.
questions.explanation: Parallel circuit: If any appliance gets damaged, the remaining ones continue to work as all appliances work independently.

questions.statement: Resistance is the measure of opposition to current flow in an electrical circuit.
questions.explanation: The measure of the opposition to current flow in an electrical circuit is known as resistance.

questions.statement: Silver is an insulator.
questions.explanation: All metals such as copper, silver, nickel, aluminium, iron and steel are conductors.

questions.statement: Rubber is a good conductor of electricity.
questions.explanation: Cotton, rubber, paper, glass, ceramics, plastic, wood and pure water are insulators.

questions.statement: Glass is a good insulator.
questions.explanation: Cotton, rubber, paper, glass, ceramics, plastic, wood and pure water are insulators.

questions.statement: Electric wires are covered with conductors to make them safe.
questions.explanation: Electric wires are always covered with insulators, such as plastic, to make them safe.

questions.statement: The human body is as good a conductor as metals.
questions.explanation: The human body also allows current to pass through it, but it is not as good a conductor as metals.

questions.statement: Power line weather coating provides insulation and protection from electric shock.
questions.explanation: They may have weather coating, but it provides no insulation or protection from electric shock.

questions.statement: You should stand on a rubber mat while doing electrical work.
questions.explanation: Stand on an insulator such as a rubber mat or a wooden board when doing electrical work.

questions.statement: It is safe to get electrical repairs done by any person.
questions.explanation: Never get electrical repairs done by an untrained person.

questions.statement: You should put off the main switch immediately in case of short circuit.
questions.explanation: Put off the main switch immediately in case of short circuit and fire.

questions.statement: A fuse is a safety device that melts when current exceeds permissible value.
questions.explanation: A fuse is a safety device containing a wire that melts and breaks the electric circuit when the current exceeds permissible value.
questions.source_section: Prepping for PISA - Fuse vs MCB

questions.statement: MCB stands for Miniature Circuit Breaker.
questions.explanation: Miniature Circuit Breakers (MCBs) are commonly used in homes and commercial settings.
questions.source_section: Prepping for PISA - Fuse vs MCB

questions.statement: MCB is less sensitive to current than a fuse.
questions.explanation: An MCB is more sensitive to current than a fuse as the MCB can detect even a slight fluctuation in voltage.
questions.source_section: Prepping for PISA - Fuse vs MCB

questions.statement: Georges Leclanche invented the Leclanche cell in 1866.
questions.explanation: In 1866, he invented the Leclanche cell

questions.statement: The Jawaharlal Nehru National Solar Mission aims at generating solar power.
questions.explanation: The Jawaharlal Nehru National Solar Mission aims at generating 1,00,000 MW of grid connected solar power by 2022.
questions.source_section: Case Study - Jawaharlal Nehru National Solar Mission

questions.statement: Distilled water is a good conductor of electricity.
questions.explanation: Distilled (pure) water is an insulator: 'No, the bulb will not glow. Distilled water (pure water) is an insulator and does not conduct electricity.
